Description: Wheel-made pottery oil-lamp with a low body, a central point and a wide overhanging rim with a beaded outer edge, which slopes in towards the centre. The tapering nozzle has a rounded tip and a large oval wick-hole. The underside is turned. Nozzle has been painted with a matt black paint. Soot on nozzle. Light brown fabric.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by Egyptian Museum, Cairo. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Similar form from Athens (Howland 1958, no. 156), parallels from Tocra and South Ionia (Bailey 1975, 1989-9). Bailey suggested a similar piece may have been made in Naukratis (Bailey 1975, 198), however an East Greece origin seems more likely. Howland, R.H. 1958. The Athenian Agora, IV, Greek lamps and their survivals, Princeton.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (KC.25) (Phase 3)
